abstract.p: This article examines the concept and design of a multifunctional composite sandwich structure for simultaneous energy harvesting and vibration control. The intention is to design a composite wing spar for a small unmanned aerial vehicle which is able to harvest energy itself from ambient vibrations during normal flight along with available sunlight. If the wing experiences any strong wind gust, it will sense the increased vibration levels and provide vibration control to maintain its stability. The proposed multifunctional composite wing spar integrates a flexible solar cell array, piezoelectric wafers, a thin film battery, and an electronic module into a composite sandwich structure. The piezoelectric wafers act as sensors, actuators, and harvesters. The basic design factors are discussed for a beam-like multifunctional wing spar with energy harvesting, strain sensing, and self-controlling functions. The configurations, locations, and operating modes of piezoelectric transducers are also discussed for optimal power generation. The equivalent electromechanical representations of a multifunctional wing spar is derived theoretically and simulated numerically. Special attention is given to the self-contained gust alleviation with the goal of using available energy harvested from ambient vibrations. A reduced energy control law is implemented to reduce the actuation energy and the dissipated heat. This law integrates saturation control with a positive strain feedback controller and is represented by a positive feedback operation amplifier and a voltage buffer operation amplifier for each mode. This study builds off of our previous research and holds promise for improving unmanned aerial vehicle performance in wind gusts. Here, we also include, but not use, a flexible solar panel in our modeling.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
A wing spar is used for fixed-wing aircraft, which includes some unmanned designs. The increasing need for high resilience and flexible lightweight structures in small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) raises structural vibration control issues induced by flutter mechanisms and gust perturbations. These considerations provide motivation for the study presented in this article. Lead zirconate titanate (PZT – although PZT commonly refers to monolithic piezoceramic material lead–zirconate–titanate, we refer to PZT for brevity but any piezoelectric material is implied) is a popular choice for energy harvesting,1 and also for integrating sensors and actuators into structures. The PZT actuators have been actuated by active control laws for flutter suppression.2–4 However, the use of batteries as power sources is a critical issue for sensing and control systems due to their bulk size and limited lifetime.5 Recent developments in microelectronics have made low power requirements possible (on the order of several hundred microwatts) for signal conditioning electronics.6 Therefore, the trend of current research mostly focuses on harvesting energy from ambient environments instead of using batteries.7 In the future, smart devices are expected to operate autonomously and facilitate self-powering, self-sensing, self-evaluation, and self-controlling from the ambient sources, such as vibrations and/or sunlight. Some recent investigations have focused on the design of self-charging devices.8–12 Some research have focused on collocated self-sensing piezoelectric actuators13–15 and the sensitivity studies of self-powered sensors.16 The motivation of this article builds off an earlier self-charging prototype for a remote control aircraft test platform,8 as shown in Figure 1. The wing spar is designed to perform self-charging during normal flight. Figure 1.
A sandwich composite wing spar for a small remote control aircraft application.8

The objective of this article is to examine the concept and design of a multifunctional composite sandwich structure for simultaneous energy harvesting and vibration control for small UAV application. In particular, the wing itself is able to harvest energy from normal vibration or sunlight, sense the wind disturbances, and alleviate wind gust by the application of reduced energy control (REC) laws developed by authors,17 which is supplied by the available energy harvested from ambient vibration. The proposed multifunctional wing spar is shown in Figure 2. For weight reduction and strength purposes, the beam-like multifunctional wing spar is designed to fit on a fiberglass composite substrate (E) of 17.8 g, with total length 593.7 mm, width 38 mm, and thickness 2.38 mm. The harvesting, sensing, and actuating PZT layers are placed at the root of the wing spar since this section will experience the largest strain during normal wing vibration or wind gust disturbance. The PZT-based harvester/sensor (B) is layered on the top surface of the fiberglass substrate. The PZT actuator (F) is layered on the bottom surface of the fiberglass substrate. The thin film battery (C) allows for power storage from harvesting and provides energy supply for wind gust alleviation. The electronic module combines conditioning, sensing, and control circuitry, on a single layer of printable circuit board (PCB). These multifunctional layers, together with the fiberglass composite substrate, form the multiple layer wing spar. 3 M ScotchWeld™ DP460 epoxy is bracketed by Kapton to be used in the individual layer layup. Both of them are grouped together as layer G. Here, we do not study energy storage, but rather a composite beam model is used here to illustrate the concept of multifunctionality. Figure 2.
Multifunctional wing spar design showing various functionalities including self-sensing, self-harvesting, self-storage, and self-control.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows: the following section presents the ‘electromechanical cantilever beam model of a multifunctional wing spar using assumed modes’; ‘Design considerations for a multifunctional composite wing spar’ discusses the design factors of the electromechanical composite sandwich wing spar to obtain optimal harvested energy; the subsequent section investigates power flows of ‘simultaneous gust alleviation and energy harvesting using REC control laws’; and ‘Conclusions’ summarizes and discusses the theoretical and numerical results.

sec.title: Electromechanical cantilever beam model of a multifunctional wing spar using assumed modes
sec.p: A major research issue in energy harvesting theories is to model piezoelectric generators accurately.18 Experimental measurements on an aluminum baseline bimorph cantilever thin beam show that the distributed parameter model is more accurate than single-degree-of-freedom lumped model.19 Later, this distributed parameter method was applied to a bimorph self-charging structure, also layered on an aluminum beam.20 However, the electromechanical cantilever beam model with collocated sensing/harvesting and self-controlling for multiple modes is yet to be investigated. This article employs a modeling method of assumed modes based on Rayleigh–Ritz formulation for a multifunctional composite wing spar. The governing equations involve not only the self-charging but also the self-sensing and the self-actuating functions of PZT transducers. In addition to the fundamental mode, the second dominant mode of the multifunctional wing spar is also predicted and controlled using REC laws.

sec.title: Electromechanical energy components using distributed parameter
sec.p: The motion of this wing spar is electromechanically coupled with the PZT transducers through strain. A closed-form electromechanical cantilever beam model is developed based on Euler–Lagrange equations (Appendix 5) that captures the basic piezoelectric constitute equations (Appendix 2). The distributed parameter variable relative vibration response wrel (x, t) at any longitude point x and time t can be represented as a finite series of admissible trial functions Φr(x) and unknown modal coordinates ηr(t) for rth mode by (1)wrel(x,t)=∑r=1NΦr(x)ηr(t)

where N is the number of terms required for convergence. The admissible trial functions Φr(x) have to satisfy the boundary conditions for cantilever beams. A common trial function 21 used here is given by (2)Φr=1-cosbig((2r-1)πx2L)

Substituting the above-assumed mode solution into the kinetic, potential, and internal energy components introduced in Appendix 5 yields the energy expressions for piezoelectric transducers. The potential energy is defined as (3)Uo,a=12∑i,l=1N[ηi(t)ηl(t)kilo,a-ηi(t)vo,a(t)θio,a]. where U represents the potential energy, and v stands for the voltage across the PZT layer. The superscript o stands for the output transducer (harvesting or sensing). The superscript a denotes the actuator. The stiffness component kilo,a is defined as (4)kilo,a=∫0LEsIsΦi″Φl″dx+∫L1L2,L3ckkEIpo,aΦi″Φl″dx where EI stands for the bending stiffness (elastic modulus E multiplied by second moment of inertia I), which is taken as a constant across each of the individual longitudinal sections. The upper limit of the second integral L2, L3 corresponds to the length of output transducer and actuation transducer, respectively, with respect to their second moment of inertia Iilo and Iila. The bending stiffness of each longitudinal section is estimated using cross-section transformation (CST) method22 introduced in Appendix 4, which is a simple version of modulus-weighted section method,23 limited to rectangular cross-section Euler–Bernoulli beam-like structures. The space-dependent bending stiffness can be represented using Heaviside step functions, described in Appendix 5.

The subscripts s and p represent the multifunctional structure and piezoelectric layers, respectively. A prime denotes ordinary differentiation with respect to the spatial variable x. Here, ckk is the piezoelectric elastic stiffness constant (k = 1 for {3-1} operating mode and 3 for {3-3} operating mode). The superscript E means the corresponding parameters at a constant electric field. Note that the piezoelectric materials use different piezoelectric constants due to different poling directions of the material (Appendix 2). For example, the monolithic d31 domain piezoelectric harvester and sensor Quick Pack (QP) satisfies the constitute equations given in equation (34). However, the micro fiber composite (MFC) 8528P1 uses the d33 operating mode, which is deformed and excited both in the 3-direction, shown in Figure 25(b), and the reduced constitutive equations satisfy equation (36).

The coupling coefficient θieo,a is defined by (5)θieo,a=∫L1L2,L3Jpo,aΦi″dx where the definition of coupling term Jp of the piezoelectric transducer over its cross-sectional area Ap is given in Appendix 5.

If wb(x, t) denotes the base displacement of the wing spar in the absolute frame of the reference at any longitude point x and time t, the total kinetic energy becomes (6)Teo,a=12∑i,l=1Nbig(η·i(t)η·l(t)milo,a+2η·i(t)∫0LρAs(x)Φi∂wb∂tdx) +12∫0LρAs(x)big(∂wb∂t)2dx where ρ stands for the mass density and As the cross-sectional area of the beam-like structure in the x-direction. An over-dot stands for ordinary differentiation with respect to the time variable t. The mass component, represented by mil is defined as (7)mil=∫0LρAs(x)ΦiΦldx
If Cp denotes the piezoelectric capacitance (see Appendix 5 for definition), the internal energy Eie becomes (8)Eieo,a=12∑i=1N(ηivo,aθio,a+Cpo,avo,a)

The forcing term fi induced by base excitation is given by (10)fi=-∫0LρAs(x)Φi(x)∂2wb∂t2dx

It is worth mentioning that the distributed damping parameters are important for accurate model predictions.24 A two-parameter damping model,25 which included viscous and strain-rate damping terms, provided the best fit to measure modal data compared to other damping methods. However, this method can only reproduce the measured damping ratios to within 85%. For simplicity, the commonly used Rayleigh damping is implemented in this article, which assumes that the damping matrix C is proportional to the mass and stiffness matrices, given as follows (11)C=κM+γK

The damping matrix must satisfy the following properties in order to uncouple the modal equations (12)2ωniζi=ΦiTCΦi=κ+γωni2 where ωni and ζi represent the ith natural frequency and its associated damping ratio. The damping ratios associated with the first and second modes were measured experimentally as 0.37% and 0.1%, respectively, using quadrature peak picking on the frequency response function (FRF) plot obtained from Siglab 20-42. The coefficients κ and γ are determined to be 1.34 and 1.89e−7, respectively.
After introducing the damping components and rewriting the Euler–Lagrange solutions (9) in a matrix form, one obtains (13)M··η+C·η+Kη=f+θovo (14)Cpov·o+voZo+θo·ηo=0

As an alternative approach, a finite element method (FEM) is implemented in Matlab to capture the three-dimensional (3D) behavior of the beam-like homogenous wing spar. Again, a 2.38 mm thick honeycomb core fiberglass host structure has a total length of 735 and width 38 mm. The hanging over length is 34.5 mm, which makes its clamped length 700.5 mm, as shown in Figure 2. Its mass is taken as 17.8 g, and its elastic modulus is taken as 59 GPa. sec.title: Design considerations for a multifunctional composite wing spar
sec.p: The increasing trend of lighter and stronger structures can be easily achieved by the use of composite materials. The sandwich composite is one of popular examples which have been tailored for many specific applications. Sandwich composites are manufactured with the central part (core) bonded between two facing layers (skins), whose major advantage is their high flexural stiffness to weight ratio. The primary demands on facing materials are high tensile and compressive strength, high stiffness, high flexural rigidity, etc. Fiber-reinforced composites with a low-density core find increasing use since they potentially provide more durable replacement for aluminum or steels in primary aerospace, marine, or automotive structures.26,27 A wide variety of materials are used as cores, such as honeycombs,28 which are required to possess a low specific weight and an adequate shear stiffness.

Recently, significant efforts have been made for energy harvesting optimization, as reviewed previously.29 In particular, Sodano et al.30 have investigated the transduction performance of three commercial piezoelectric devices, PSI-5H4E, QP, and MFC, in order to recharge nickel metal hydride batteries. Their experimental studies showed that QP and PSI-5H4E are more efficient in the random vibration environment. Bilgen31 identified harmonic vibration based harvesting characteristics of MFC, PZT-5 H, PZT-5 A, and PMN-PZT with respect to different configurations and material properties of the host structure. The MFC was developed in the NASA Langley Research Center.32 The use of interdigitated electrodes and piezo-fibers improves the MFC actuation authority and performance, making them popular for vibration control.33,34 He concluded that monolithic polycrystalline and single crystal piezoelectric offer better harvesting capabilities than the MFC. But the MFC is more practical for large strain aerodynamic applications, since it has a much higher actuation voltage range. However, those conclusions are based on energy harvesting devices under a certain frequency excitation and a fixed load resistance. This section discusses the basic design factors for the multifunctional composite wing spar, such as optimal load resistance, active length, location, and operating modes of piezoelectric transducers. The maximum power generation is the main design factor to be considered. The focus is on ambient vibration transduction caused by atmospheric turbulence, where the ambient vibration source is simulated using Dryden’s power spectral density (PSD) function (Appendix 6).

sec.title: Harvesting effects on operational modes
sec.p: The first comparison focuses on operational modes of two MFC devices with the same mechanical configurations: MFC 8528P1 and MFC 8528P2. One can tell from Table 1 that the former one in {3-3} operational mode has higher piezoelectric constant and coupling coefficient, but much lower capacitance than the latter one in {3-1} operational mode. In addition, load impedance also has an effect on optimal power output, which can be observed from equation (21). The clamped end of the multifunctional wing spar is excited by ambient normal wing vibration, which is simulated using Dryden PSD function (see ‘Generation of normal wing vibration and wind gust signals’ for more details).

Figure 4 compares power output for MFC 8528P1 and MFC 8528P2 against different load resistances for the first two modes. Both types of MFC are placed on the clamped end. The plots in Figure 4 show that a P1-type MFC harvests much more power at larger optimal load resistance compared to P2-type MFC. Here, the acceleration unit is g = 9.81 m/s2. It is worthy to mention that the P1-type MFC also has a higher actuation voltage range −500 V to +1500 V compared to the P2 type of −60 V to +360 V. Figure 4.
Output power versus load resistance at mode 1 of 29 Hz and mode 2 of 180 Hz.

The results presented in Figure 4 show that the optimal load resistances for MFC 8528P1 are 1.98 MΩ for mode 1 and 72 kΩ for mode 2. Another popular piezoelectric harvesting device is QP group provided by MIDE Technology, Corp. As shown in Table 1, consider a QP10n for example. It operates in the {3-1} mode, has larger elastic modulus and capacitance, but smaller size, mass, piezoelectric constant, and coupling coefficient, compared to MFC 8528P1. Using the same method, load resistances of 112 and 21 kΩ are found to be the optimal values for QP10n at the first and second vibration modes. Plots for QP10n are not shown here for brevity, but are compared next with MFC 8528P1, with respect to another important design factor: the location of the piezoelectric transducers.

sec.title: Harvesting effects on position of the piezoelectric transducer
sec.p:
It is known from vibration textbook35 that for a cantilevered beam, all higher vibration modes other than the fundamental mode have certain strain nodes, where the bending strain distribution (at a constant level from the neutral axis) changes sign for a vibration mode. It is also reported that covering these strain nodes with continuous electrodes results in cancellation of the electrical outputs and therefore a reduction of the energy harvested from the respective vibration nodes.36 For the given configuration of the cantilever composite harvester in this article, as shown in Figure 2, the strain node of the second mode is found to be 12.2 cm away from the clamped end. Figure 5 plots power output of MFC 8528P1 at an optimal load resistance of 1.98 MΩ against the distance from clamped end (0.5–6.5 mm) at the first and the second vibration modes. One can see that the power output from the second mode has a more significant reduction, especially when approaching to the edge of covering the strain node. Figure 5.
Output power of MFC versus distance from the root at mode 1 of 29 Hz and mode 2 of 180 Hz.
MFC: micro fiber composite.

Figure 6 presents the power output of QP10n at optimal load resistance of 112 kΩ against the distance from the clamped end (0.5–6.5 mm) at the first and the second vibration modes. Figure 6.
Output power of QP versus distance from the root at mode 1 of 29 Hz and mode 2 of 180 Hz.
QP: Quick Pack.

sec.title: Optimal active length of the piezoelectric transducer
sec.p:
It is known that the strain energy in the cantilever piezoelectric harvester varies along the active length of the transducer itself. It is reported theoretically and experimentally that the harvested energy in the fundamental mode maximized with an active length (electrode coverage) of exactly 2/3 of the beam length from the root, without considering any additional materials (tip mass).37 This prediction was observed based upon static beam theory and applies for dynamic loads as long as the beam mode shape is the same as the static case. Figures 7 and 8 shows the output power of MFC and QP versus their active length, respectively. For the given cantilever wing spar, the 2/3 beam length gives 37.28 cm. The output power plot at the fundamental mode, as shown in Figure 7, validates favorably with maximum power predication when the active length covers at 2/3 of the beam length from the root (37.28 cm). For the second mode, the harvested power reaches maximum when the active length is 43 cm from the root, and the minimum power output (cancellation) occurs when the active length is 16 cm from the root. Figure 7.
Output power of MFC versus active length at mode 1 of 29 Hz and mode 2 of 180 Hz.
MFC: micro fiber composite. Figure 8.
Output power of QP versus active length at mode 1 of 29 Hz and mode 2 of 180 Hz.
QP: Quick Pack.

The plots of QP in Figure 8 shows that the output power at the fundamental mode reaches maximum when the active length (35.6 cm) covers less than 2/3 of the beam length from the root. The output power at the second mode reaches maximum when the active length is 44 cm from the root. The minimum output power occurs when the active length is 17 cm from the root.

The reason why the optimal active length values of QP are different from those of MFC is mainly due to the changing position of PCB and storage battery, as shown in Figure 2. These devices have to be moved toward the free end to the cantilever wing spar due to the outspread of the QP. For the simulation of each active length, the PCB and storage battery are put 3.85 cm away from the further edge of QP from the root. The changing position of PCB and storage battery also affects the harvester power of QP.

Note that the harvester power of MFC and QP is obtained at their optimal resistive load at each active length. The variation of active length changes the piezoelectric capacitance and therefore the optimal resistance load. Figures 9 and 10 illustrates the optimal resistive load at the first and the second vibration modes versus each active length for MFC and QP, respectively. Figure 9.

MFC: micro fiber composite. Figure 10.

The results presented above provide a platform to build off when choosing an appropriate piezoelectric transducer for optimal energy harvesting. In addition, for best actuation authority concern, a {3-3} effected MFC 8528P1 is selected as an actuator for gust control, due to large actuation voltage range and high coupling coefficient.34 QP10n is selected as the piezoelectric harvesting and sensing layer due to its relatively high harvesting efficiency with normalized mass. Both MFC and QP layers are placed right next to the clamped end.

sec.title: Simultaneous gust alleviation and energy harvesting using REC laws
sec.p: This section discusses the possibility of a two-mode wind gust control using REC for small UAVs using the harvested energy from ambient wing vibration based on the multifunctional composite concept developed in the previous sections. First, an electromechanical equivalent circuit is described for representing a multifunctional wing spar. After that, an estimation of harvested power and control power is analyzed.

sec.title: Equivalent circuit representation of a piezoelectric generator
sec.p:
The equivalent circuit of a piezoelectric generator has been derived using the single-degree-of-freedom method.38 It has also been derived using the distributed parameter method.39 This article creates an equivalent circuit in Matlab Simulink using distributed solutions presented by equations (13) and (14), for multiple-mode harvesting. Figure 15 shows the equivalent circuit for the first mode, where the piezoelectric generator is modeled as a current source. Here, Cps is the piezoelectric capacitance of QP10n. The induced current matrix [B] and voltage matrix [A] are derived from electromechanical coupled governing equations (13) and (14). Figure 15.
The equivalent circuit for first mode piezoelectric generator with resistive impedance.

A resistance impedance of 112 kΩ is implemented to maximize the harvested power efficiency of the wing spar. The harvested voltage-to-base acceleration FRF for the first two modes is presented in Figure 16 at this optimal load resistance. The assumed mode formulation is truncated at an order of 50 to insure the convergence of the first two modes. The ambient normal wing vibration is simulated with 0.02 g RMS acceleration over a frequency bandwidth of 5–300 Hz. Figure 16.
The output voltage-to-base acceleration FRF for a 112 kΩ load resistance.
FRF: frequency response function.

The spectrum of the instantaneous harvested power for an 112 kΩ resistive load is plotted in Figure 17. Figure 17.
The harvested power spectrum at optimal load resistance 112 kΩ.

sec.title: Generation of normal wing vibration and wind gust signals
sec.p: The aerodynamic loads on a wing in flight are never constant. Therefore, the induced ambient vibration provides an energy harvesting source for UAV during normal flight conditions. The nature of atmospheric turbulence is influenced by many factors, see Etkin40 for instance. The PSD provides the designer information of how the mean squared values of the argument is distributed with frequency ω. Two classical PSD functions for representing atmospheric turbulence are the Von Karman and the Dryden spectrum.41 Due to its simple form, the Dryden PSD spectrum in Appendix 6 is adopted here for modeling the ambient vibration source.

In order to generate the clear sky wing vibration and cumulus cloud gust signals with the required intensity and scale lengths for a given flight velocity and height, a Gaussian white noise source n(t) ∼ N(0,1) with PSD function of 1 is amplified by a gust gain Kg and filtered by a wind gust transfer function Gv(s). The relationship between the PSD of the output signal vg(t) and the input signal n(t) is given by (23)Φv(ω)=Kg2|Gv(ω)|2ΦN(ω)
If the power spectrum of the noise source is chosen as a Gaussian white noise, i.e. ΦN (ω) = 1, then the wind gust transfer function becomes (24)|Gv(ω)|2=Φv(ω)/Kg2

The solution of equation (23) yields (25)Kg=3σv2U0πLv, Gv(s)=s+U03Lvbig(s+U0Lv)2 where Lv is the vertical scale of turbulence, σv the RMS vertical gust velocity, and U0 the aircraft trim velocity, which is given by42 (26)U0=2Wρ∞SCLtrim. where W represents weight of the aircraft, S the wing area, CLtrim the trim lift coefficient, and ρ∞ the free stream density in kg/m3, which is altitude dependent. Equations (23) to (26) are employed to address ambient vibration, which is used to excite the cantilever wing spar. The small UVA trim velocity is chosen as 15 m/s, and the vertical scale of turbulence as 350 m. Figure 18 shows an example of simulated clear sky wing vibrations (dotted line) and cumulus cloud wind gust (solid line) signals, in acceleration units of g = 9.81 m/s2. Figure 18.
Ambient wing vibration and wind gust acting on multifunctional wing spar base, U0 = 15 m/s and Lv = 350 m.

sec.title: Gust alleviation using REC control laws
sec.p: If one defines the self-sensing sensitivity16 as the derivative of the sensing voltage vs with respect to the PZT covered strain Sxxs, the following relations can be derived from equation (14) (27)∂vs∂Sxxs=hysd31c31ECpo=d31c31Ehpoɛ31Shxs where hys and hxs represent the width and the length of the piezoelectric sensor, respectively. The piezoelectric constants and permittivity constants are denoted by d31 and ε31. Note that the current flow into the sensor is neglected since the impedance is very high. Once cumulus cloud wind gust is detected, QP10n works as a strain sensor and provides feedback signals into the controllers.

Conventional active control laws usually suppress vibration very efficiently, but consume large amounts of external power. However, the REC control law was reported to be able to not only suppress vibrations efficiently but also reduce the required power significantly. Our previous experimental results17 show a 67% energy reduction when using on–off switching REC laws for transient vibration control, compared to their conventional active control counterparts. Here, REC laws are implemented for gust alleviation over the frequency band covering the first two modes. sec.title: Power flow for simultaneous energy harvesting and gust alleviation
sec.p:
The REC laws produce a non-linear switching logic by saturating the actuating voltage provided by the positive strain feedback (PSF) controller. The PSF control algorithm takes a similar transfer function form as the positive position feedback control law.17 However, the feedback signals act from the PZT strain sensor instead of a position sensor. This collocated approach removes external sensing sources and/or external power supply. As seen from Figure 22, the Laplace transfer function of PSF for the first mode, driven by a PSF operation amplifier (op-amp) and a voltage buffer op-amp, is of the following form (31)vovi=kωf2s2+2ζfωfs+ωf2. where the PSF filter parameters gain k, damping ratio ζf, and filter natural frequency ωf are given by (32)k=R2R1big(1+R5R4),ωf2=1C1C2R2R3,ζf=C1(R2+R3)ωf2. Figure 22.
Block diagram of PSF control for the first mode.
PSF: positive strain feedback.
where C1 and C2 are capacitance components, and R1, R2, R3, R4, and R5 resistive components.

In Figure 22, the voltage buffer op-amp is added to reduce actuation current flow. Two parallel PSF controllers are designed for gust alleviation for two specific modes. The PSF feedback signals are periodically saturated to satisfy the REC switching logic17 (not demonstrated here to save space). The instantaneous power associated with the actuator is defined as the product of actuation voltage and actuation current (33)Pins(t)=v(t)ai(t)a

Note that the piezoelectric actuation voltage is associated with the REC laws, and the actuation current depends on the electrical impedance of the control circuits. The real and imaginary parts of the cross-spectrum between instantaneous voltage and current represent the active (real) and reactive powers associated with a given component, respectively. The active power (thick line) and reactive power (thin line) associated with each PSF and buffer op-amp of the first and the second modes is presented in Figure 23. The unit of active and reactive power is watt (W) and volt–ampere reactive (var), respectively. The plot shows that the op-amp for the first mode control require 90 times more active power than that of the second mode. Figure 23.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A novel concept of simultaneous energy harvesting and gust alleviation is presented in this article. The motivating application is a multifunctional wing spar of a UAV with the goal of providing self-contained gust alleviation. A wing spar is designed to be compatible with collocated self-harvesting, self-sensing, and self-controlling functionalities using piezoelectric materials. The basic design factors are discussed for a beam-like multifunctional wing spar with energy harvesting, strain sensing, and self-controlling functions. The configurations, locations, and operating modes of piezoelectric transducers are also discussed for optimal power generation. The REC law is implemented to reduce control power while preserving control performance. Theoretical modeling and numerical simulations show that the tip displacement due to a wind gust disturbance can be reduced by 28 and 37 dB for the first and the second modes, respectively, using energy harvested from ambient wing vibrations. A flexible solar panel is also modeled but not used in the analysis. Future work will focus on solar energy harvesting in order to reduce the recharging time substantially. Another consideration for future work is finite element modeling for optimized multifunctional structures.

sec.title: Piezoelectric constitutive equations
sec.p: This appendix summarizes the standard 3D form of constitutive equations for piezoelectricity. Reduced 1D forms are presented for both {3-1} and {3-3} operating mode piezoelectric transducers.

sec.title: Standard 3D form of constitutive equations
sec.p: According to IEEE Standards on Piezoelectricity,43 linear piezoelectricity can be represented by four standard sets of constitutive equations, by taking two of the four field variables as the independent variables. The field variables are the mechanical strain Sij, the mechanical stress Tij, the dielectric charge displacement Dk, and the electrical field strength Ek. All of these four sets describe the same piezoelectric phenomena. For studies of damping effects, the mechanical stress and electric field strength are more often taken as the independent variables.44 However, for investigations of energy harvesting, the mechanical strain and electric field strength are the more popular independent variables.45 The corresponding constitutive equations become (34)Tij=cijklESkl-ekijEkDi=eiklSkl+ɛikSEk where c represents the elastic stiffness constants, e denotes the piezoelectric constants and ε indicates the permittivity constants. The superscripts E and S denote the corresponding parameters at constant electric field or constant mechanical strain, respectively. The subscripts i, j and k are tensor notations.

sec.title: Reduced equations for {3-1} operating modes
sec.p: For cantilever configurations with piezoelectric transducers satisfying the Euler–Bernoulli beam assumptions, the only non-zero stress component T1 is in the axial direction.46 If the piezoelectric transducers are under a {3-1} operating mode, the constitutive equations can be reduced to (35)T1=c11ES1-e31E3D3=e31S1+ɛ33SE3

As illustrated in Figure 25(a), the {3-1} mode PZT-based transducers are excited under force fp in the 3-direction and deformed by wp in the 1-direction. The monolithic d31 domain PZT-based harvester and sensor QP10N satisfies the constitute equations given in equation (35).

sec.title: Reduced equations for {3-3} operating modes
sec.p: For the piezoelectric transducers operating in the {3-3} operating mode, such as MFCs, their interdigitated electrode configurations are deformed and excited both in the 3-direction, as shown in Figure 25(b). Assuming that the electrode region is electrically inactive, whereas the region between the electrodes utilizes the full {3-3} effect, the linear constitutive equations for cantilever configuration under 3-3 operating mode can be reduced to (37)T3=c33ES3-e33E3D3=e33S3+ɛ33S*E3
The piezoelectric coefficients in the {3-3} mode are given by (38)big{c33E=S11ES11ES33E-(S13E)2e33=S11Ed33-S13Ed31S11ES13E-(S13E)2ɛ33S*=ɛ33T-(S33Ed312)-2S13Ed31d33+S11Ed332S11ES33E-(S13E)2}

sec.title: Euler–Lagrange equations using extended Hamilton’s principle
sec.p: For a given structure, the total kinetic energy Te is a function of the generalized coordinates and their time derivatives, denoted by (39)Te=Te(q1,q2…qn,q·1,q·2,…q·n)
The total potential energy Ue and internal electrical energy Eie are functions of the generalized coordinates, denoted by (40)Ue=Ue(q1,q2…qn,q·1,q·2,…q·n)Eie=Eie(q1,q2…qn,q·1,q·2,…q·n)
If the non-conservative work is denoted by Enc, the extended Hamilton’s principle over a given time period satisfies the following relation (41)∫t1t2(δTe-δU+δEie+δEnc)dt=0
The Euler–Lagrange equations can be derived and represented by (42)ddt∂Te∂q·-∂Te∂q+∂U∂q-∂Eie∂q=∂Enc∂q

sec.title: Cross-section transformation
sec.p:
If a multilayer beam is made of layers with rectangular cross sections, the CST method is a simple way to compute an equivalent modulus.48 Taking a four-layer beam as an example, shown in Figure 26, the dimensions of the cross section in the y-direction are transformed using the equation h~k=(Ek/Eref)hk. Here, Eref is the modulus of elasticity of the reference material (layer C) on the cross section and hk and h~k the original and transformed widths of each layer (k = A, B, C, D). Figure 25.
Piezoelectric transducers with: (a) {3-1} operating mode and (b) {3-3} operating mode. Figure 26.
CST of original beam (a) and transformed homogeneous beam (b).
CST: cross-section transformation.
The total bending rigidity thus can be written as (43)EIyy=∑Ek(Iyy)k=ErefI~yy

The location of neutral axis y in the composite beam is determined from the following equation (44)ηc=∑ηkEkAk∑EkAk where ηk is the location of the centroid of the kth layer as measured from a common datum line.

sec.title: Energy formulations of electromechanical cantilever beam using distributed parameter method
sec.p:
The multiple layer beam structure provides multifunctional abilities, such as energy harvesting, strain sensing, and vibration control, and also introduces complex static and dynamic characteristics. The approximate distributed parameter model was derived analytically and validated experimentally49 for cantilevered piezoelectric energy harvesters. This appendix summarizes the energy formulations of the electromechanical cantilever beam using a distributed parameter approach, which will be applied for equivalent electromechanical model prediction. This summary is for Euler–Bernoulli cantilever beams with multiple PZT-based transducer layers in the general case, as shown in Figure 27. Figure 27.
Representation of a Euler–Bernoulli cantilever beam with multiple PZT layers.
PZT: Lead zirconate titanate.

The total potential energy U in the cantilever beam structure can be written as (45)U=12∫VSxxTxxdV where Sxx and Txx denote the stress and strain vectors of the host structure and the PZT-based transducers over the whole structural volume V. If wrel(x, t) stands for the displacement relative to the clamped end of the beam, at an arbitrary position in the x-direction along the neutral axis, and at a given time t, the non-zero strain component is given by (46)Sxx(x,z,t)=-z∂2wrel(x,t)∂x2

According to the Hooke’s law, if the beam is linearly elastic, the structural stress Txx is the product of the global elastic modulus Es and the strain vector Sxx. Thus, the structural strain energy becomes (47)Us=12∫0LEsIsbig(∂2wrel(x,t)∂x2)dx where Es Is stands for the bending stiffness of the structure, which is taken as constants across each of the three individual longitudinal sections in Figure 27. The bending stiffness of each longitudinal section is estimated by CST method introduced in Appendix 4. The space-dependent bending stiffness can therefore be represented using Heaviside step functions (48)EsIs(x)=E1I1[H(L1-x)H(x)]+E2I2H(L2-x)H(x-L1) +E3I3H(L3-x)H(x-L2)

Again, here x is the longitude coordinate, as shown in Figure 27. According to the constitutive equations (35) and (37), the stress components in PZT transducers under dji operating mode are given by (49)Ti=ciiESi-ejiEj where Si represents the strain vector Sxx in the x-direction. Since the voltage v(t) across the PZT layers is the product of the thickness of each PZT layer with the instantaneous electric field Ej(t), the total strain energy in each PZT layer becomes (50)Up=12∫VPbig[ciiEz2big(∂2wrel∂x2)2+zeji(t)v(t)hp∂2wrel∂x2]dv

The subscript p denotes the piezoelectric layer. The bending stiffness of each PZT layer is derived using the parallel axis theorem. If the coupling term Jp of the piezoelectric transducer over the cross-sectional area Ap is defined as (51)Jp=∫∫Ap-zejihpdydz where hp represents the thickness of the PZT layer, then equation (50) becomes: (52)Up=12∫0x1big[ciiEIpbig(∂2wrel∂x2)2-Jpv(t)∂2wrel∂x2]dx

If w(x,t) denotes the transverse displacement of the multifunctional beam in the absolute frame of the reference base, the total kinetic energy of the multiple layer beam structure Te can be represented by (53)Te=12∫0Lρ(x)As(x)big(∂w(x,t)∂t)2dx where ρ(x) stands for the density and As(x) the cross-sectional area of the beam structure in the x-direction. The internal electric energy of the PZT layer can be expressed by (54)Eie=12∫VpEjDjdVp

After substituting the expressions for the electric field and the electric displacement from the constitutive equations (35) to (37) in Appendix 2 into equation (54), the internal electric energy becomes (55)Eie=12∫0x1Jpv(t)∂2wrel∂x2dx+12Cpv(t)2 where the capacitance term Cp of the PZT transducer is defined as (56)Cp=ɛjisAphp where Ap denotes the electrode surface area of the PZT transducer. Since the base excitation from ambient vibration is accounted for in the kinetic energy, the only non-conservative work done by the PZT transducer is (57)Enc=Q(t)v(t) where Q denotes the electrical charge across the PZT transducer.

sec.title: Dryden PSD spectrum
sec.p: At any particular frequency ω, the PSD of any function x(t) is the mean squared value of that part of x(t), whose frequency is within an infinitely narrow band, centered on ω. It provides the designer information of how the mean squared values of the argument are distributed with frequency ω. For a given function of x(t), its PSD function is given by (58)Φ(ω)=limT,δω→01TΔω∫0Tx2(t,ω,Δω)dt where Φ(ω) is the PSD function of x, T the duration in seconds of the record of x (t), and x (t, ω, Δω) the component of x (t) which lies within the frequency band ω ± Δω/2.

The Dryden PSD spectrum is a popular and accepted way to represent the PSD function of atmospheric turbulence, since it is simpler and more easily programmed compared to other approaches. The definition of the Dryden PSD spectrum50 can be represented by (59)ΦDry(ω)=σv2LvπU01+3big(LvωU0)2big(1+big(LvωU0)2)2 where U0 is the aircraft trim velocity. Lv is the vertical scale of turbulence and σv the RMS vertical gust velocity. In arriving at these representations, the following assumptions are made:
The atmospheric turbulence is a stationary random process.
The vertical gust velocity σv for clear air, cumulus cloud, and severe storm are 0.5, 2.0, and 4.0 m/s, respectively.
The turbulence scale length varies with height and follows the definition of by Chalk.51
